for people who need support.Elsewhere, in the outlying parts of the Dunpender community ndash Whittingehame, Tyninghame and Whitekirk ndash residents continue to help their neighbours with shopping to avoid unnecessary journeys.The Lynton Centre has been delivering three-course meals to members and to those aged  and over or who are disabled and in need of this service.It can be contacted on  .A rota of its volunteers has been phoning members every day to keep their spirits up while they are unable to come to the Day Centre for social contact.Judith Priest, chairwoman of Dunpender Community Council, told the Courier: ldquoLocal shops here in East Linton have done a great job, making sure they have plenty of supplies and clear safety guidelines for shoppers.ldquoHome deliveries are available from The Mart and Linton Butchers."There is an organic vegetable stall at Phantassie on Saturdays and Bostock Bakery has been very popular, with cyclists stopping for a takeaway coffee and croissant.ldquoBarneyrsquos Coffee Shop is now open for a selection of gts and, of course, takeaway coffee and cakes, plus afternoon teas can be ordered for a treat delivered to your home.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus can be found at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or by going to www.eastlinton.ukPeople can also contact   or  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickQUILT makers in North Berwick are making a special lsquolockdown memoryrsquo quilt which they are hoping will be hung in the townrsquos community centre.Law Quilters, who celebrated their th anniversary last year, have been busy throughout the coronavirus crisis making quilts for ious uses in hospitals, hospices and womenrsquos refuges.They include lsquoLinusrsquo quilts for children, heart-shaped cushions for mastectomy patients and quilts for incubators, as well as face coverings.All of the quilt grouprsquos  members will be participating in the lockdown memory quilt.Moira Cochran, Law Quilters president, who is a retired nurse, said the group had come up with a number of images which will be included in the quilt.They include the unique signage warning people to stay two metres apart, baking ndash which has become incredibly popular during lockdown ndash a supermarket trolley full of toilet rolls, a computer screen with a Zoom meeting on it, rainbows, puffins and face coverings.Moira added: ldquoWe will also feature a lsquoThank You NHSrsquo image and a row of houses to represent the street links in North Berwick.Meanwhile,  volunteers led by Khlayre Cairney from North Berwick Resilience Group have stitched  face coverings so far from the cotton pillow cases and duvet covers donated to the community centre.ldquoTo date we have issued supplies to Astley House, North Berwick Day Centre, Tantallon Court, families being supported via the North Berwick Community Centre, and our own North Berwick volunteers, said Khlayre.Finally, more computer tablets have been distributed to care homes in the North Berwick area to enable residents to see and speak to relatives online.Three have been delivered to Fidra House care home, two to Leuchie House and another two to the Edington Cottage Hospital.North Berwick Rotary is working with North Berwick Community Councilon this project, which has received a grant of pound, from the Foundation Scotland Community Response Fund.This grant was made to NBCC specically for this project.Contact detailsAs usual,residents need help with shopping or prescriptions, they can go to www.nbresilience or phone  .

title: community-resilience-happening-cockenzie-port-seton-dirleton-longniddry-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie and Port Seton has started to plan for how its work can continue once schoolsin August.The effort is being led by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.Bryan Hickman, group chairman, said: ldquoWe are working on what we will do when the schools go back. We will continue as best we can till then.ldquoWe are making plans.ldquoWhen the schools do go back, at the moment the plan is that they wonrsquot all go back at once so we might need to help families and kids while they are not at school.The resilience team is also discussing how its support efforts can continue during the easing of lockdown restrictions.The group received a third consignment of childrenrsquos craft packs from Walk With Scott Foundation, which are now being delivered throughout the community.The packs include items such as crayons, bee and butterfly colouring sheets and a butterfly feeding kit.Bryan extended his thanks to those at the Walk With Scott Foundation for their generous donation.Work on the sports hall extension at the Port Seton Centre has resumed after it was paused due to the coronavirus.Bryan told the Courier that the contractor was back on site and had resumed work on the pound million extension.Work initially started in October last year, with the hope it would be completed next month.Contact detailsThose in isolation, who are housebound or require assistance can still contact the team on  .Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonVOLUNTEERS have vowed to continue offering support to people throughout Dirleton despite lockdown restrictions being eased.The Dirleton Area Resilience Teamis continuing its ongoing support for the local community.With the easing of pandemic restrictions and the lockdown, it has continued to be at the forefront of planning for, and critical analysis of, the situation.DARTrsquos primary services remain the same, with shopping and prescription requests being completed, dog walking being carried out and volunteers on hand to provide support when needed.David Tait, DART lead co-ordinator, said: ldquoAlthough the village and wider area seem to be gradually ing to normal, we are in no way complacent in our approach to the support we give.ldquoWe continue to monitor the situation on a day by day basis and we have contingency plans in place, ready for roll out in any eventuality ndash such as a possible second spike of the virus or to provide support to families who may be at risk when the furlough scheme is wound down and with the possibility of job losses.ldquoWersquore monitoring the position and we aim to keep our community up to date on whatrsquos happening as soon as we know about it.Meanwhile, the community essentials larder remains a vital asset within the village, with an increase in regular visits.The larder had been set to move to more permanent premises but this has been delayed.Jack Findlay, landlord of the Castle Inn in the village, has allowed DART to extend its time at the premises with the larder.David added: ldquoWithout Jackrsquos generosity we would have lost this vital asset, one on which our community continues to depend.ldquoWe are forever grateful to Jack and his family for the support they are giving to the DART team.ldquoThere arenrsquot enough words out there to thank them for their kindness.Contact detailsFor continued and up to date information on DARTrsquos activities, go to www.dirletonresilience.orgLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryTHE resilience effort in Longniddry is still available for people who need to use it and the local dental practice has introduced new rules as part of its reopening during phase two of the easing of lockdown restrictions.Anyone who needs to contact the practice is asked to call first, as the door will be locked.People will be asked screening questions before appointments, which they are encouraged to attend alone.There will be hand sanitiser at reception and the toilet will remain closed.Appointments will be spaced out to allow for social distancing.People are being encouraged to pay using contactless methods and staff will be wearing additional PPE.Meanwhile, despite not receiving a lot of requests for help, the resilience effort is still available for those who need it.Longniddry residents can also benefit from the food pantry in Port Seton Centre.The pantry is open pm to pm, Monday to Friday.Delivery can be arranged by calling  .There is also a food pantry at the Pennypit Centre in Prestonpans, from am to pm.Contact detailsIf anyone needs support or assistance of any kind, they are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS community resilience effort is now looking at winding down some of its volunteer activities as members of its teamto work and demand for support reduces as people who have been shielding are allowed to got out under an easing of restrictions.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said thoughts were turning to winding down resilience work after more than three months of ldquotremendous effort.But he stressed that the hardship fund set up by the community council to help those finding it dficult in lockdown remainsed and anyone who needed support could still call the resilience team for help.He said: ldquoOur thoughts are turning to winding down our resilience efforts. ldquoThere has been a tremendous amount of work put in by our volunteers in Prestonpans since the start of lockdown on March  and we cannot thank them enough for their support.ldquoAt the start of this, our volunteers delivered leaflets to every household in the Pans and during the past three months have delivered meals and shopping, collected food donated from supermarkets, collected prescriptions for people self-isolating and shielding and last, but not least, walked the dogs for people unable to get out.ldquoThe relaxation of the rules by the Scottish Government allows our volunteers to start to wind down but their magnicent efforts on behalf of their local community should not be forgotten.ldquoWithout their selfless efforts the past three months would have been a lot tougher for many people living in Prestonpans.Brian added: ldquoWhilst the work of our resilience volunteers is quietening down, le at the Pennypit Pantry carries on, with food parcels being delivered daily to the elderly, and many families now collecting food from the Pagoda in North Grange Avenue.ldquoLast week, the Pantry provided  meals to the elderly and families in Prestonpans, which included almost  deliveries each day.Anyone in Prestonpans who needs support with meals or essential groceries can call the Pennypit Pantry on   or email lornabellany@gmailAs well as the Pennypit Pantry, Jane Russellrsquos Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners are still being provided, and last weekend they delivered  dinners.Sunday dinners can be ordered via East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners via its Facebook page or by calling  .Contact detailsAnyone who needs help can contact the team by calling their hotline telephone number on   or by emailing them at prestonpansresilience@gmail

story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Gford. involved in the scheme.He said: ldquoIn the last week, we have done a lot of work with the lending library.ldquoA lot of the focus has been on making sure people are getting books and games, which are helping them with their mental health.ldquoWe have got about  items out in the first week.ldquoVolunteers Pat Lemmon, Graham Samuel and Fiona McEwan have been doing a sterling job.A website has been weeks to determine the role of volunteers as society moved forward.Many of the volunteers will be going back to work but Chris was confident they would remain able to cope with demand.He added: title: six-new-things-can-today-scotlands-lockdown-eased
story: The First Minister last week confirmed an acceleration of easing restrictions across the country following a continued suppression of the virus.But Nicola Sturgeonhas since urged the public not to ldquosquander that progress as we move into more freedom.Here, we detail out the six changes taking place today:Shopping and outdoor marketsOne of the most anticipated announcements from lockdown, non-essential shopsare now officially allowed to reopen.The one restriction still in place, however, is these must be street-access retail. Non-essential stores within shopping centres malls must remain closed until Phase .Commenting on the re-opening this morning, the First Minister tweeted: ldquoIf you plan on visiting shops today, please do so responsibly.ldquoMaintain physical distancing, follow hygiene advice, wear a face covering and respect staff who may be asking you to shop dferently.ldquoWersquove made so much progress against the virus ndash letrsquos not squander it. #StaySafe.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.On Friday, First Minister @NicolaSturgeon set out guidance on how to #StaySafe when some shops reopen today following changes to #coronavirus measures.Find out more ## https:t.co DwqbXAFMk pic VVuUhPzZWorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .This does NOT include indoor workspaces that are due to open in Phase  ndash like non-essential offices and call-centres.Moving homeFrom today, all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.The Scottish Government has issued guidance around this ndash as well as encouraging people to take part in virtual property viewings as much as possible with further guidance around health and safety here.Outdoor sports courts and playgroundsFrom today, outdoor sports courts can reopen to the public.This includes courts for tennis, basketball, volleyball , Multi-Use Games Areasand netball.Participants must maintain strict physical distancing at all times when using outdoor sports courts. This does not include pitches used for contact sports.Playgrounds can also reopen.These were closed at the start of lockdown amid fears the virus could spread through the physical contact in these areas.Marriages and civil partnershipsMarriages and civil partnerships can resume from today.These have to have a minimal number of attendees and, despite the Scottish weather, be outdoors only.All the participants, including the couple and the witnesses, must come from no more than three households and will be possible up to amaximum of eight.The celebrant or registrar will not count as one of the households.Zoos and garden attractionsMust to the anticipation of those in Edinburgh, zoos and garden attractions can open from today.However the Scottish Government guidance says these are initially for local access only ndash meaning people broadly within five miles can attend.Increased hygiene measures are encouraged, with pre-booking tickets online also advised.

title: east-lothian-council-shop-local-campaign
story: East Lothian Council has launched a campaign for residents to lsquoStay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothianrsquo by using local shops and businesses.With many businesses hit hard by the Covid- pandemic, retailersacross the county re-opened this week and introduced social distancing measures to keep customers and staff safe.And the council is calling on people to back their local shops and services by using them while following safety advice.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos Provost and spokesperson for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoEast Lothianrsquos shops and local businesses have had to face particularly challenging circumstances over the last few months, but, as our high streets start to open up again, they are keen to welcome existing and new customersldquoIrsquom delighted to support the launch of East Lothian Councilrsquos new campaign ndash Stay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothian.ldquoItrsquos about sending out a message that East Lothian is getting back open for business ndash whatever products or services yoursquore looking for, yoursquore very likely to find them here in East Lothian.ldquoLocal businesses are essential for our economy. They bring growth and innovation, provide employment and support the local economies and communities. They also care about their community.ldquoBy continuing to stay safe and shop locally the people of East Lothian can help local businesses, so integral to the fabric and character of our community, to not only survive but thrive.The campaign comes as East Lothian councillor Craig Hoy, who is the Scottish Conservative candidate for the Holyrood  election, launched a locallsquoSupport Our High Streetsrsquo campaign.Mr Hoy has already called on the council to make it easier for local restaurants, cafes and bars to re-open by allowing them to use public space near their venues to provide al fresco services.He said: ldquoWith East Lothianrsquos shops re-opening, itrsquos vital that we Support Our High Streets, save jobs and help the local economy bounce back.ldquoWe can all do our bit by making sure we shop local and visit our fantastic range of cafes, restaurants and bars as they begin to re-open.

title: east-lothian-council-safe-space-funding
story: The local authority has been given pound.million of Scottish Government funding to allow it to transform its high streets and bring shoppers back.However, the plans have sparked concern among some residents, who questioned whether the council would use the money to introduce long-term changes proposed before lockdown which brought mixed reactions form the public.One person on social media accused them of using a ldquoback door to get what they want.While Haddington councillor Craig Hoy warned that improvements had to be made without creating unnecessary restrictionsHe said: ldquoIt is important that our high streets are capable of allowing pedestrians to be able to socially distance, giving people the confidence to get out and about.ldquoBut, at the same time, itrsquos important we donrsquot impose unnecessary restrictions or reduce parking provision in a way which is detrimental to trade.ldquoWe need to strike a careful balance here and ensure the interventions are proportionate.The local authority launched its bid for funds from the Spaces for People Fund last month with a public consultation online.It drew just under , responses, with  detailed comments about improvements for town centres and roads.Although the funding is for temporary measures, the online questionnaire asked those taking partthey would support changes ldquolong term.Many people who took part in the survey called for pavements to be widened and speed reductions on some streets, as well as improved cycle lanes and footpaths.The council initially said it was applying for pound, from the Spaces for People Fund but has revealed it received nearly four times the original amount.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader and environment spokesperson, said: ldquoThe pound.m funding will enable East Lothian Council to introduce a number of temporary measures to our streets as further easing of lockdown restrictions are applied.ldquoMany local shops are re-opening for business and these temporary changes are focused on protecting public health by providing necessary space for continued observance of physical distancing whilst supporting businesses and their customers.ldquoWhilst planning these new temporary changes, we have taken into account the erse needs of local communities to ensure as much as possible that those with mobility or sight concerns will be as supported as able-bodied iniduals.ldquoThese measures will create space for everyone, whether on foot, bike, wheelchair or using prams and buggies, and will support the initial stages of local economic recovery.The council said detailed plans of the changes to be introduced were still being discussed and no maps or additional information were currently available.However, it said a staged approach would be taken, with measures to be introduced including temporary widening of some footways, mph speed limits, some segregated space for cycling and opportunities for businesses to use pavement space for customer queuing.Some parking spaces within town centres may be temporarily removed.

title: rare-lunar-eclipse-visible-glasgow-weekend---need-know
story: One of only eight to occur this decade, all eyes will be on the skies early on Sunday morning.Here, we bring you everything you need to know ahead of the penumbral lunar eclipse.A penumbral lunar eclipse takes place when the moon moves through the faint, outer part of earths shadow.A lunar eclipse happens when the Earth comes between the sun and the moon, therefore blocking some or all of the sunrsquos light from reaching the moon.Therefore, the moon cannot shine ndash because its surface is not reflecting the sunrsquos rays.The eclipse will be visible over ScotlandAccording to TimeAndDate, a penumbral lunar eclipse occurs when the sun, earth and moon are imperfectly aligned.When this happens, the earth blocks some of the sunrsquos light from directly reaching the moonrsquos surface, and covers all or part of the moon with the other part of its shadow.People in Scotland are urged to find an unobstructed area with a free sight to the southwest for a best view of the story: Mckenzie Kearsley-Edmond celebrated turning  on June  and received a signed picture of Josh Taylor in action.However, it was a present he could not unwrap that really floored the youngster.Taylor, , took time out from his training regime to film a short video wishing Mckenzie, who hopes to follow in the boxerrsquos footsteps and join Lochend Amateur Boxing Club, a happy birthday.His dad Chris Kearsley, who lives in Dunbar, said: ldquoIrsquove never seen him so emotional in my le. He was just about in tears of happiness.The incredible gt came about through Chris, who is a self-employed joiner, getting in touch with Jenner Charlton.The Duns-based photographer has been a regular at Taylorrsquos fights and was able to not only arrange for a signed picture of the boxer in action against Ryan Martin but also line up the birthday message.Taylor, from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, said: ldquoHi Mckenzie, hi wee man, happy birthday.ldquoHope you have a great day and Irsquoll see you at Lochend [Amateur Boxing Club] one day when it opens back up.ldquoWersquoll do a bit of training together.Mckenzie, who is going into P at Dunbar Primary School, has been clocking up the miles watching ldquohis hero.He has taken in fights in Glasgow and even met Taylor in unusual circumstances before the county fighter lted the IBF World Super Lightweight title against Ivan Baranchyk.His dad said: ldquoWe were staying at the Radisson RED in Glasgow and got into the lt on the seventh floor.ldquoThe lt stopped on the sixth floor and Shane and Barry McGuigan and Josh all got in and we got a picture with them.Mckenzie and his dad even travelled to London in October to see Taylor put his newly claimed world title up against Regis Prograis and his WBA World Super Lightweight championship.Chris said: ldquoIrsquove always been a boxing fan and kept up training for the last wee while.ldquoWe started following Josh and found out he was from Prestonpans.ldquoWe went to watch his fight with Viktor Postol in Glasgow, and Lynne Wilson [an ASN auxiliary at Dunbar Primary School] is Joshrsquos cousin.ldquoWe started going to Joshrsquos fights and Mckenzie became interested in boxing.ldquoHe joined the Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent and was doing a bit of training there.ldquoWe went to all the World Boxing Super Series fights and went to the final in London against Regis Prograis.ldquoMckenzie was on cloud nine for a week afterwards it was a great atmosphere!

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said that "as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors.""This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well," she said.When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said  patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from  on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why the Border must regain its old role as the country   s first line of defence
story: Yet she is clearly unsettled at the idea of some kind of checkpoint on the A, A, or whichever route she might take. Speculation over testing or quarantining travellers between England and Scotland has been raised as part of a discussion of how to prevent infection from a neighbour with a higher incidence of Covid  than here. As a result, almost overnight the Border has begun to assume a signicance it has not held for centuries.:Thousands back petition to close Scottish border to all but essential trafficThis pandemic might one day be viewed as a textbook illustration of the geopolitical fault lines across the UK. What was once a united front has splintered into four distinct nations, each with a dferent solution to the same problem. Nothing more starkly demonstrates the gulf between the laissez-faire ethos of the Westminsterrsquos panjandrums and the commonsensical attitude at Holyrood than the ways in which they have eased restrictions.The increasingly relaxed English regime appears to be fuelled by wishful thinking rather than science the Scottish situation, meanwhile, is characterised by caution. Long before talk of checkpoints, this was already causing tension. When Englandrsquos routemap out of lockdown was weeks ahead of Scotland, John Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, said those of his constituents close to Borisrsquos bailiwick were confused. Why did one rule apply to their very near neighbours, and another to them The answer seemed obvious ndash it was far too soon to relax ndash but the question vividly demonstrated the nature of this area. Many who live where Hadrianrsquos men boldly marched have a foot in both countries. They might work in one, and live in the other, hail from this side and have relocated to that. They could have family and friends in either camp, who remained out of reach for so long as the Scottish government prohibited meeting.Those Border villagers who defied lockdown to visit a garden centre in Berwick were making a political rather than a horticultural statement. In this, they echoed attitudes since the days of the great reiving clans, who roamed freely on both banks of the Tweed. The Scottish and English kings were so appalled at the regionrsquos lawlessness that, despite being sworn enemies, they worked in tandem to subdue it.Given the way Borderers were treated by their lieges, itrsquos no surprise they thumbed their noses. These days, towns and villages are awash with folk from both sides, thereby creating a unique and strongly bonded region. Little wonder Unionism still pertains hereabouts.:Tourists from England could face -day quarantine in ScotlandCovid- cases flareThat there have been no deaths from Covid  in Scotland for the past few days suggests we are heading in the right direction. But there is a long way still to go. The First Ministerrsquos aim is to eradicate the virus, not merely contain it. Seeing the daily tally of new cases and deaths in England, she seeks confirmation that the Prime Minister has the same objective. But, as she said earlier this week, without such assurances she fears Englandrsquos strategy is ldquoletting it circulate at higher levels as long as it doesnrsquot threaten to overwhelm the NHS.If that is indeed the case, then monitoring passage between the countries is in some respects no dferent from policies implemented by a place like New Zealand. It initially imposed an outright ban on entry, followed later by quarantine on new arrivals. The problem is, as a devolved nation within a union, the consequences of such a step are potentially inflammatory. Some will view it as independence by stealth, a confrontational declaration of autonomy, or simply authoritarianism run rampant. Yet with a summer of staycations approaching, the repercussions of allowing untrammelled travel could be dire.Before the prospect of imposing controls was mooted, people around where I live in Roxburghshire have been scowling at visitors from only a few miles away, let alone the depths of the English shires. When a couple of walkers dared ask a neighbour directions over the hills last week, they narrowly avoided a tirade.The idea of the Border ing to its roots as a frontier inevitably creates a troubling sense of Them and Us, or Friend and Foe. Affront will be taken at any restriction on free transit between south and north. Presumably residents of Scotland who visit England will also be tested or quarantined on their , making it a two-way injunction. Suddenly a weekend break in Northumberland looks a lot less appealing.:YouGov Poll: Half of Conservative voters in England support English independenceYet how exactly would it work  Is it only tourists who will be checked, or will those travelling back and forth for work, be they lorry drivers or business reps, also be subject to testing  Will every road, rail and sea route across the Border from Berwick to Workington be patrolled  Might we see a surge in midnight crossings over no-manrsquos land and rivers, four-by-fours finally justying their existence and canoes retrofitted to ferry families plus their luggage across the Tweed As things stand, there have been no new cases of the virus in the Scottish Borders in two weeks. This beautul, windswept district is starting to feel like a cordon sanitaire, a buffer between the haves and,not precisely the have-nots, then a population beginning slowly but steadily to paralyse the disease.Given our reputation as one of the sickest countries in Europe, we need to take every precaution to protect lives. Reimposing the Border as a barrier and guard would not be popular, and the war-time and military resonances are unsettling. Yet, in light of the high risk of contagion still posed by parts of the south, in the short term it would make sense. If the first thing passengers see as they arrive is not a sig welcoming them to Scotland but an NHS squad, then for the first time since  ndash the last pitched battle between England and Scotland ndash the Border will have regained its old role as the countryrsquos first line of defence.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: letters-jewish-strongly-object-tarnished-state-israels-brush
story: I am Jewish by birth and by upbringing but live in the belief that whatever Maxine Peake wrote about Israel, its police, its conspiracies, its network of support all over the place, whether factually correct or not, and whatever Rebecca Long-Bailey retweeted, is nothing whatsoever to do with me. But Sir Keir Starmer and others who believe that such comments are anti-Semitic are implying that because of being Jewish, I am somehow implicated. Indeed the belief that Jews in general are somehow associated with Israel and are under attackthe actions of the Israeli State are attacked is itself anti-Semitic. Anti-Semitic and racist, because it implies that the ethnicity of someone Jewish, not their citizenship, or their own views on the world is their defining characteristic, and that this ethnicity necessarily associates them with Israel.So, Sir Keir, please desist: I do not want whatever Israel and its agents are up to be laid at my door.I would add that those who most detest some of what Israel is up to, such as Maxine Peake, are the least likely to be at all racist in outlook. Whereas at the opposite pole many of those who blindly support Israel in everything it does, such as the Christian Right in the US, will include many who are truly racist and anti-Semitic in outlook, and detest Jews as such.Denis Rutovitz, Edinburgh EH.MAXINE Peake is widely reported as making a claim that the Israeli Secret Service taught American police the tactic of kneeling on a victims neck.Now, this claim is unsubstantiated, as far as I can see, and directed at an Israeli institution, but how is it anti-Semitic The Israeli secret service is Jewish, of course, but is her claim an attack on Jewry in general, or on the Israeli state that might have sanctioned such a barbarous policy of suffocating someone in order to subdue them I find the blurring between what is Jewish and what is Israeli deeply concerning. Are we not allowed to criticise anything the Israeli state might endorse  Are we not allowed, for example, to criticise Israeli settlement expansion into the West Bank as de facto occupation of territory that is not theirs  Are we not allowed to even suggest that Israeli policy towards Palestinians might have unpleasant similarities with South-African apartheid  Is this anti-Semitic The debate about what constitutes anti-Semitism has long been getting out of hand.Trevor Rigg, Edinburgh EH.

title: agenda-choice-new-cabinet-secretary-important
story: First, Mr Frost as the National Security Adviser. This is a far less serious matter than his becoming Cabinet Secretary. It has few,any, constitutional implications. I worked for a previous incumbent for a couple of years. It is an extremely important role but, as its name suggests, it is primarily advisory ndash and also a kind of personal envoy from the Prime Minister to counterparts overseas. That could be work for a trusted political appointee.:Agenda: Proposed new law could make JK Rowling a criminalIs it a good appointment  That is a more subjective question, and less fundamental. Mr Frostrsquos predecessors have been very senior diplomats, with deep grounding across Britainrsquos foreign policy and security concerns ndash former heads of the Diplomatic Service, Ambassadors in Washington, Paris, Permanent Representatives in Brussels, both to the EU and to Nato. Some have done more than one of these big jobs, in wide, senior international careers.Mr Frost is able and, importantly, has the Prime Ministerrsquos confidence. But his diplomatic career culminated in the important, but not central, ambassadorship to Denmark. He then ran the important, but not central, Scotch Whisky Association, and was special advisor to Mr Johnson, as a Foreign Secretary who earned mixed reviews. Judging Mr Frostrsquos role as chief Brexit negotiator may be premature. But it is odd, after the justied criticism of Sir Mark Sedwillrsquos being both Cabinet Secretary and National Security Adviser, that Mr Frost should have to combine the climax of Brexit negotiations with whatever Middle Eastern politics, for instance, or terrorism, may serve up in the coming months.Choosing the new Cabinet Secretary matters more. Britain wonrsquot acquire a written constitution any time soon. Much therefore depends on working through complex but broadly respected conventions. Over the last  years, as government has grown, so has the Cabinet Secretaryrsquos role as a constitutional . He ndash no ldquoshe yet ndash advises the Prime Minister on constitutional issues and questions of propriety, as well as maintaining the good order of Cabinet business and co-ordinating departments. Often, though not always, he has been Head of the Civil Service too.:Agenda: How to overcome the challenge of online studyingThere is therefore good reason for the common background of most Cabinet Secretaries to include formative service in the Treasury, and senior, repeated exposure to No, often as Private Secretary to one or more Prime Ministers. They know about Parliament, the economy, cross-Whitehall management, and political and media realities. With a mainly diplomatic background, Mark Sedwill has lacked his predecessorsrsquo grounding in our curious constitution: this must have been a challenge. Eventhose appointing his successor want a revolution in Whitehall, it would be goodhe or she thoroughly understands the constitutional arrangements to be overhauled, within which crises are bound to happen. Not least, in an increasingly scandal-prone world, the Cabinet Secretary should have a neutral authority to make judgments on erring ministers and officials that command respect across the political and public scene. Letrsquos hope these are the aims.George Fergusson is a retired senior diplomat

story: The people most at risk of contracting the virus from tourists would presumably be those who are heavily involved in the tourist industry, such as hotel, shops and visitor attraction workers, and all who live in popular beauty spots, such as seaside towns on the Clyde coast. Given that Councillor Gallagher writes from Largs, I would have expected him to appreciate the First Ministers determination to protect the health and wellbeing of his constituents, along with the rest of the population.Ruth Marr, Stirling.MAY I put a question to Alex Gallagher  Let us concoct a fantasy that Labour in Scotland is still a political force of some consequence, and that the Government now sitting in Holyrood is a Labour one. In this fantasy, everything  ndashTory government in Westminster with Boris Johnson as Prime Minister, Covid pandemic still very much in being ndash is the same as todayrsquos actual reality. In such a situation, would Mr Gallagher not expect Scotlandrsquos Labour government to put the case for Scotlandrsquos receiving UK Government funding according to its particular requirements  Andit did so, would he describe this as ldquobegging Derrick McClure, Aberdeen AB.ALLAN Sutherlandsuggests that the First Minister should take a ferry over to Northern Ireland to find out ldquohow they used their shaky devolved powers to overcome what were told is the biggest crisis to face the UK since .Might I suggest one reason, appertaining to geography: that their neighbourhas suffered . deaths per , of their population from Covid-, compared to the UKrsquos  per ,. In contrast, we know that Covid- cases in Scotlandrsquos neighbour, England, have been ldquothe worst in Europe, just above Spain, to quote the BBC on June .Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.IN several letters recently Rev Dr Robert Anderson seems to want to vent a great deal of real anger and anathema towards the First Minister and the Scottish Government in general.It makes me wonder which Bible he is reading such is the strength of what may be described as his vitriolic prose and sentiments. .From a gentleman who is clearly very knowledgeable about the Bible the nature of the prose and sentiments seem very surprising and concerning.For example such apparent anger is totally negated by John  verses  to  where mercy, grace and forgiveness are seen in abundance.There may be reasons for Dr Anderson wishing to "cast the first stone", but the Christian ethic teaches the exact opposite of this and we should all try to state our opinion with humility and kindness.Linda C Park, Stirling.THE US has bought up most of the coronavirus drug Remdesivir in an "international heist".As the Westminster regime now aims to secure a great trade deal through the Special Relationship after Brexit, one can now point out to whose sole advantage that will be.John Edgar, Kilmaurs.

title: gaelic-communities-unlikely-survive-beyond-decade-unless-action-taken
story: Researchers found the social use and transmission of Gaelic is at the point of collapse in the remaining ldquovernacular communities where it is still in regular, day-to-day use.They said that under current conditions, Gaelic speakers ldquodo not have the demographic or societal resources to sustain a communal presence in the islands beyond the next  years, except for isolated networks of elderly speakers.The study, the most comprehensive of its kind, found low levels of Gaelic ability in those under , as well as indference among the young to the place of Gaelic in their lives.The findings are contained in a new book, the Gaelic Crisis in the Vernacular Community: A Comprehensive Sociolinguistic Survey of Scottish Gaelic.:Surge in online Gaelic learners during coronavirus lockdownProfessor Conchuacuter Oacute Giollagaacutein, director of the University of the Highlands and IslandsrsquoLanguage Sciences Institute and one of the books authors, said: ldquoUnless the language is used in the community, it canrsquot survive, and thatrsquos where the danger is. If we continue on the current trajectory, it will only be the elderly that have any appreciable experience of speaking Gaelic in the community.He added: ldquoIf the public bodies wish to continue with existing policies, we will have no vernacular, native-speaking community anywhere in Scotland.Mr Oacute Giollagaacutein is the director of Soillse, a research collaboration between the UHI and several other universities aimed at informing public policy towards the maintenance and revitalisation of Gaelic.The new book emerges from the work of Soillsersquos Islands Gaelic Research Project, conducted between  and , and focuses on the use and transmission of Gaelic in the Western Isles, in Staffin on the Isle of Skye and on Tiree in Argyll and Bute.Detailed analysis of census data from  to  shows the rapid decline of Gaelic from  onwards.In the areas examined,  per cent of people reported an ability to speak Gaelic in  compared to % in .The study found that for every -year period since , there has been a % proportional average loss in Gaelic speakers.This represents an average loss of , each decade from  to .It estimated there are currently around , Gaelic vernacular speakers.Researchers found the projected Gaelic-speaking population in the Western Isles will be at the threshold of the ldquomoribund category by next year, where the language is largely restricted to marginal aspects of community le, institutional practice and the elderly.A survey of Gaelic language ability and practice among preschool children throughout the research areas found fewer than % of responses indicated either fluent, native levels of spoken Gaelic or understanding of Gaelic on enrolment.Elsewhere, a questionnaire completed by  to -year-olds in four secondary schools in the Western Isles found that while around % of teenagers reported fluency in Gaelic, only .% said they always or mainly speak Gaelic to their friends.:Alan Simpson: It is time to rip up the Gaelic blueprint and start againThe researchers argue that current policy provision displays a "general bias in favour of Gaelic learners and potential future secondary bilingual speakers at the expense of existing vernacular speakers and their communities".The ongoing economic and demographic challenges in the Western Isles and other island groups also exacerbates the issue.The book suggests creating a new Gaelic Community Trust , based in the islands and under the direct control of a representative group of community members.It argues there should be "an admission by the community and public bodies that the situation is critical an acceptance among public bodies that the current policy interventions for the Gaelic vernacular speaker group are not fit for purpose and an acknowledgement that an alternative approach is requiredthe complete loss of vernacular Gaelic is to be averted".Mr Oacute Giollagaacutein said the remaining native-speaking Gaelic communities in the islands are on the point of societal collapse.He said: "If we continue as we are, we will have Gaelic policy, Gaelic bodies but no Gaelic group."A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Gaelic language is a vital part of Scotlandrsquos cultural identity and ministers support efforts to improve access for speakers to learn and use the language.ldquoWe are interested in the proposals in the book and look forward to discussing the value of current initiatives and the new structures suggested to strengthen Gaelic in the islands.ldquoAlthough the Gaelic language is in a fragile condition there are a range of policies and interventions in place to promote the learning, speaking and use of Gaelic in the islands and these are constantly kept under review.Mairi MacInnes, chair of Bograverd na Gagraveidhlig, said it welcomes any research that contributes to an understanding of Gaelic.:In tune with nature: Music contest celebrates Scotlandrsquos beauty spotsShe said: "Our understanding is that one of the key messages from the research is that for the older generation of Gaelic speakers in the islands, Gaelic was and remains the default language of the community. For most younger people, the default language is now English. "This finding will come as no surprise to anyone who lives in the islands or anywhere  and is a pattern that you will find in minoritised language communities across the globe."Education policy in the Western Isles recognises the challenges for an indigenous minority language from a similar previous study and now all children enter Gaelic medium education unless they choose to opt out."It has also been the success of Gaelic medium education that has led to the growth in numbers of speakers outwith the Western Isles, with, for example, the Glasgow Gaelic school is regularly one of the top performing schools in Scotland."

title: unacceptable---nearly-half-scotlands-vulnerable-face-difficulty-getting-basic-food
story: It comes after reports of care home workers forced to queue in busy supermarkets several times a day for basics like bread and milk - risking further spread of the virus - because they could not secure the delivery slots that they needed to provide for their residents.The survey by Which , found that almost halfof situationally vulnerable respondents in Scotland, including older people who require help accessing food, faced challenges getting groceries in the week before they were surveyed.The consumer organisation Which  research rom th May to th June found the Scottish response washigher than the UK average where two in fivehad problems.:Coronavirus: Why GPs working in Scotlands most deprived communities believe a tsunami of trouble lies aheadBrian Sloan, chief executive of Age Scotland called on the Scottish Government to take urgent action. He said: ldquoItrsquos unacceptable that so many vulnerable older people in Scotland are still finding it dficult to access food more than three months into this crisis.ldquoWersquore joining Which  to call for urgent action from the Scottish Government to ensure that no vulnerable person is left struggling to access basic food supplies.ldquoAs lockdown eases for many of us, we have to remember that in Scotland there are tens of thousands of older people who will be shielding until at least the end of this month. They have to have continued access to priority delivery slots and guarantees that they can get essential groceries when they need them.ldquoWe recognize the work done by supermarkets at the start of the crisis to help customers, but it appears that some of the most vulnerable older people are still not getting the service they so desperately need. We look to the Scottish Government to work with the retailers to come up with a solution as a matter of urgency.The research uncovered what was described as an "alarmingly mixed picture" with similar issues to Scotland in Wales, whle just one in four in England registered food issues and two in five in Northern Ireland.The study found that in Scotland well over a thirdwere relying on friends and familyand supermarket deliveriesto get food and essential groceries. Just under a quarterhave been visiting supermarkets.Over three in four vulnerable consumers in Scotland said itrsquos been more dficult to get food in lockdown.Other concerning reports given to Which  included a -year-old lady who had to wait  weeks for her first food parcel despite registering in week one and a -year-old with shingles who had to wait a month between supermarket click and collect slots.Among the shielded group - those who are the most high-risk to coronavirus and for whom the most help, including priority supermarket delivery slots and food parcels, has been offered - Which  found that there was still a very high proportion of people facing dficulty getting the food and essentials needed in the week they were surveyed.This figure was highest in England where a thirdof those shielding had struggled, while three in in Northern Ireland, over a quarter in Scotlandand a quarter in Walesalso faced dficulties.Which  said it was concerned that while the easing of lockdown restrictions may make le easier for people who are comfortable with and able to go into shops again, there is still a huge risk that many of those who have already been struggling will now be cut further adrt as they may still not be able to leave their homes to get groceries - especiallyit involves long queues, taking a taxi or using public transport.The consumer organisation is calling for access to free food boxes, priority delivery slots and other relevant assistance to be made available for as long as medical advice or practical restrictions, such as social distancing, are in place. The help should be extended to include not only the most-high risk but also those who are situationally vulnerable and have so far been sidelined.This would mean that central and local governments will need to accurately assess and identy which consumers remain vulnerable so that they can also be given access to appropriate support such as priority supermarket delivery slots or local food provision through other means.:Edinburgh womanwho has battled cervical cancer and brain tumours fronts new UK-wide Cancer Research fundraising appealSue Davies, head of consumer protection and food policy at Which  said:ldquoIt is a real concern that months into lockdown, the current system of food provision is still not working for so many of those who need it the most. Some people could now be looking at a clf edge where shielding restrictions are lted and they are left to fend for themselves, cut off from outside help in getting essential groceries.ldquoWhich  is now calling for the UKrsquos four governments to work with the food industry, local authorities and charities to ensure a longer-term plan for supporting all of those who are at risk and need support is in place by the end of July, so that no vulnerable person faces dficulties in accessing the basic food supplies they need.Commenting on research by Which  showing vulnerable people in Scotland are struggling to access food supplies, Scottish Labour MSP Elaine Smith said: ldquoThese concerning findings raise serious questions about both the UK and Scottish Governmentrsquos handling of the emergency response to the pandemic. Now more than ever, we have a duty to protect the most vulnerable people in our society, and it is clear that many in this category have been failed.ldquoThis has exacerbated the longstanding and growing issue of food poverty in Scotland. Last week I launched a consultation on my parliamentary bill to enshrine the right to food in Scots Law, and the current public health crisis has underlined the need to take action.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWe recognise that the impacts of coronavirushave meant that many iniduals, including those at increased risk of severe illness, face increased food insecurity.ldquoTo support iniduals to access the food and other essentials they need, we established a national helpline and have provided pound million of funding for local authorities to extend support for those at risk until the end of September. This is in addition to the pound million allocated in April and pound. million allocated to extend Free School Meal provision over the summer holidays.ldquoWe have committed to continue to provide funded grocery packages for those who need them until the end of July, in line with shielding advice, and have awarded around pound. million to support third sector activity on food, including up to pound. million for FareShare.

title: 78-back-extending-putins-rule-russian-constitutional-change
story: In the week-long balloting that concluded on Wednesday, .% voted for the changes and .% voted against, with all precincts counted by Thursday morning, Russiarsquos Central Election Commission said.The turnout exceeded %, according to officials, with the reported numbers reflecting the highest level of voter support for Mr Putin in  years.:Russians vote on changes for Putin to stay in power until In the  presidential election, .% of voters supported his candidacy, while in the  election only .% did.But Kremlin critics say the numbers are , with an unrealistic approval rating for the Russian leader amid widespread frustration over declining living standards.ldquoA record in falsying votes has been set in Russia, opposition politician Alexei Navalny said in a Facebook post. ldquoThe announced result has nothing whatsoever to do with the peoplersquos opinion.The presidentrsquos approval rating was at % in May, according to the Levada Centre, Russiarsquos top independent pollster. That was the lowest in two decades.:Trump lsquocalls Putin with plans for international summit with RussiarsquoThe week-long plebiscite was tarnished by widespread reports of pressure on voters and other irregularities, with independent election observers criticising the voting procedure as having a complete lack of transparency and independent control.For the first time in Russia, polls were kept open for a week to bolster turnout and avoid election-day crowds amid the coronavirus pandemic mdash a provision Kremlin critics denounced as an extra tool to manipulate the outcome, as ballot boxes remained unattended at night.Observers also pointed to the relentless pressure state and private employers put on their staff to vote, monitoring that was hindered by bureaucratic hurdles and virus-related restrictions, and the dubious legal standing of the early voting.

title: new-zealand-health-minister-resigns-following-series-gaffes
story: David Clark had earlier described himself as an ldquoidiot for breaking the nationrsquos strict lockdown measures and then last week appeared to blame a beloved health official for border lapses, generating an angry reaction from the public.Mr Clark said he had put all his energy into the job as he announced his resignation.He said: ldquoBut it has become increasingly clear to me that my continuation in the role is distracting from the governmentrsquos overall response to Covid-.While New Zealandrsquos health response has been praised around the world after it managed to eliminate community transmission of the virus, Mr Clark has been widely ridiculed.:New Zealand records two new cases of Covid- after country eradicated virusHis latest gaffe came last week when he appeared to place the blame for allowing some ing travelers to leave quarantine without being tested with the director-general of health, Ashley Bloomfield.Mr Bloomfield, who was standing behind Mr Clark while he spoke, appeared stung by the criticism as he frowned and looked away in a video captured by local outlet Newshub and viewed tens of thousands of times.Mr Bloomfield has been the countryrsquos trusted medical expert and public face of the virus response mdash similar to doctor Anthony Fauci in the US.Mr Clark was stripped of some of his responsibilities in April after defying the countryrsquos strict lockdown measures.He drove  miles to the beach to take a walk with his family while the government was asking people to make historic sacrices by staying at home.He said at the time: ldquoIrsquove been an idiot, and I understand why people will be angry with me." alt"HeraldScotland: New Zealand Health Minister David Clark, centre, previously had the support of Jacinda Ardern as the country could not afford to change his role earlier in the pandemic " class"editor-image"New Zealand Health Minister David Clark, centre, previously had the support of Jacinda Ardern as the country could not afford to change his role earlier in the pandemic Prime Minister Jacinda Arden said then that she would normally have fired him but the country could not afford massive disruption to the health sector as it fought Covid-.However, on Thursday she accepted his resignation, saying in a statement it was ldquoessential our health leadership has the confidence of the New Zealand public.She added: ldquoAs David has said to me, the needs of the team must come before him as an inidual.Mr Clark said on Thursday he intends to remain in parliament as a backbencher.

title: create-luxurious-dream-home-experts-silver-birch-interiors
story: AT the age of , joiner Alan MacGregor was a man with a plan.ldquoAyoungman with a plan and a van, he says, with a laugh. ldquoWhen I first started out, it was just me with a toolbelt and an title: scottish-students-defer-university-fees-return
story: Research firm Progressive polled Scottish university applicants living in Scotland on behalf of the University and College Unionand found % would be more likely to defer university this yearthey had to pay tuition fees.Around % of respondents who provided more detail said they would not be able to go to university because of the fees.% said it would no dference to them and % said they would opt for a university outside of Scotland while % said they did not know.UCU said the poll showed how tuition fees would lead to a reduction in the number of students entering university ndash and at a time when the number of international students in Scotland looks set to plummet.UCU Scotland official Mary Senior said: ldquoAs well as it being morally wrong to charge students for tuition, we can also now say with confidence that it makes no economic sense. Bringing back tuition fees - either upfront or after graduation - would damage Scottish universities finances.ldquoUniversities across the UK are in crisis with forecasts of a catastrophic fall in the number of international students.ldquoWe need to do everything we can to support universities in the coming months as they are integral to finding a vaccine for Covid- and in driving the economy forward nationally, and as anchor institutions in their local communities.ldquoAs well as the Scottish and UK governments stepping in to help, the key to keeping universities going is maintaining student numbers and not deterring potential applicants.ldquoThis poll highlights how charging tuition fees for students in Scotland would lead to a further reduction in the number of students, rather than provide additional income for universities.Progressive polled  applicants between June  and .

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said that "as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors.""This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well," she said.When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said  patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from  on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: future-education-write-new-chapter-history-learning-together
story: It used to be said that Scotlandrsquos education system was the envy of the world. That may no longer be the case but as any number of commentators have said in recent weeks, a crisis such as the Covid- pandemic also presents us with an opportunity, a once-in-a-letime chance to do things dferently and better.Until last week, doing things dferently was a proposed lsquoblended learningrsquo model. The Scottish Government has since scrapped that idea due to a combination of falling infection rates and parent pressure, so instead the nationrsquos children will nowto full-time schooling on August .Only time and the progress of the Covid- virus will tell whether this is a prudent decision, but itrsquos clear that the pandemic will continue to have a profound impact on every single aspect of education in Scotland.Whether itrsquos the rapid expansion of the use of technology in mainstream schooling or the still unknown effect of any major drop in the number of overseas students attending our colleges and universities, education in Scotland is about to experience progressive and fundamental change.So, as we approach a new academic year, itrsquos with this almost overwhelming dynamic in mind that The Herald is launching a new campaign ndash The Future of Education.This campaign will provide a forum for debate and discussion around some of the immediate challenges facing the education sector as they prepare toto a school-based setting.It will also seek to create an environment for parents, teachers, government, policy makers and wider civic Scotland to ask the question hellipldquowhat should the future of Scotlandrsquos education look like and how do we get there .We are looking for partners to help lead the discussion around all aspects of learning in  and beyond,such as:These are just a few of the themes our Future of Education campaign will set out to explore over the next  months.With a network of local, regional and national news brands, Newsquest is uniquely placed to host a pan-Scotland discussion on the evolution of learning in the post-Covid era.By bringing together the power of our audience reach and high quality editorial content, our campaign will seek to be the leading  for debate around all the key issues, in partnership with leading education institutions, commercial organisations and public bodies.These discussions will take place across our traditional print titles, niche publications, websites, digital display and social media channels.We will also look to bring high profile thought leaders together for debates and presentations through a series of webinars and digital round-tables.The Heralds The Future of Education campaign will seek to drive the national debate, influence the decision-makers and chart the changes that are about to unfold over the coming academic year.

title: buy-face-masks-independent-stores-scotland
story: The new rule comes just two weeks after passengers on public transport were told they must cover their faces when travelling.Some Scots across the country have already been practising the habit of wearing face masks when out in public, but as covering up becomes a legal requirement, many of us are now in the market for a quality face mask.:Face coverings mandatory in Scotlands shops - what are the rules and who is exempt Of course, major fashion brands such as ASOS, Boohoo and River Island were quick to get in on the action and are selling masks online.Butindependent and Scottish-made masks are more your style, here is our rundown of where in Scotland is selling the worldrsquos latest hot commodity.With Scottish cashmere at its heart, luxury clothing brand Brora began producing face masks for both adults and children from the surplus material at one of their Portuguese factories making PPE.Edinburgh store manager Sophie Hopkinson said: ldquoWe really wanted to come up with a great idea to give back, so pound from every mask will go to NHS charities and other small charities.ldquoThey are really nice to wear since theyrsquore a natural fibre, and ever since we opened theyrsquove been incredibly popular."When the pandemic hit, engineer and entrepreneur Gavin McAdam got to work creating masks.His Edinburgh-based start-up Breathe Easy began by asking only for donations to try and help the third-party care sector and vulnerable groups get access to quality medical-grade face masks.And when someone got in touch askingMr McAdam could create a face mask for their deaf son, the company set about creating and trialling a cotton face mask with a transparent plastic face .Now Breathe Easy continues to issue free face masks to a iety of charities around Scotland, but also sells both full cotton masks and those with transparent  for deaf and hard of hearing communities on their website.Owner Gavin McAdam said: ldquoWersquore growing all the time and employing more people to keep up with demand.ldquoWersquore also working in partnership with the National Manufacturing Institute and Glasgow University in the development of a novel material that has natural microbial properties, engineered to capture the exact particle size of the Covid- virus."We will be trialling the first of these masks in two or three weeks."Slanj Kilts recently came into the limelight when Nicola Sturgeon was seen wearing one of their latest wares.The First Minister was spotted modelling the homeless tartan design, which sees % of all its sales donated to Shelter.General Manager Ross Lyall said: ldquoWe started making face masks in February in anticipation of lockdown. Sales were trickling through, but then of course Nicola wore our mask, and it went mental.ldquoThe traditional kilt business is dependent on the wedding industry, so we were very worried about the way things are at the moment and asking ourselves where the money is going to come fromthere are no weddings.ldquoSuddenly we had thousands of orders going through, so we are currently trying to recruit as many sowers as possible to keep up with demand.As an Aberdeen-based brand known for its lingerie, this company is now also producing cloth masks in a iety of dferent colours and prints, with a pocket for a filter, for only pound..Designer Hazel Lethaby, founder of Mischke Lingerie said:"We have a passion for making small and beautul things and firmly believe that the Devil is in the detail."I started making masks as I saw a need to use my skills to produce something for the general public so that there was no need for people to buy up supplies of medical grade equipment."The masks I make are not designed as PPE but can be worn to comply with the guidelines in stores and on public transport."I am using mainly % cotton gingham as it has a stylish and playful look and its easy to wash, making the masks more sustainable. The design is also zero waste, there are no offcuts!"Owner of this Kirkaldy bridal store Mirka Jankowska has been hard at workcollaboratingwith Laila Letteringto produce limited edition face masks during lockdown.For each face mask purchase Mirka Bridal Couture are donatinga face mask to the Childrenrsquos Oncology Ward in Edinburgh who are in need of reusable face masks for their young patients and their families.Julie Macintyre, from Dalkieth near Edinburgh has pressed pause on making bags to create beautul Harris Tweed face masks.After trialling several designsshe found that the above product, with % cotton lining, was most comfortable to wear.This independent store has added face masks to its list of handmade items, which already includes bottle light lamps, hand-knitted items, handmade cards, and jewellery.The face masks come in a wide range of colours and patterns, are washable and double lined with a filter pocket.

title: scottish-teachers-in-state-uncertainty-less-quarter-feel-safe-return-august
story: Nicola Sturgeon has stressed that "safety matters" as plans are drawn up for pupils tofull time in August.But asurvey by the NASUWT union has revealed that only  per cent of teachers said they feel safe or very safe as a result of measures to mitigate the risks of Covid-.:poundm plans to extend school day for Scottish pupils to catch-up on missed lessonsThe study also found that almost half of teachers said they do not feel prepared toto their school or college in August.NASUWT general secretary, Patrick Roach, said: ldquoGiven the abrupt eleventh hour changes announced by the Scottish Government just as schools and colleges were preparing for the summer break, it is little wonder that so many teachers do not feel that schools and colleges are prepared for the fullof pupils in
